message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest subacute thyroiditis, which is characterized by mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. Option A describes the histopathologic findings of Riedel’s thyroiditis, option B describes medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and option D describes papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination and laboratory findings suggest subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (also known as De Quervain's thyroiditis). The most likely histopathologic finding in this condition is mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. Extensive fibrosis of the stroma is seen in Riedel's thyroiditis, sheets of polygonal cells in amyloid stroma in medullary thyroid carcinoma, and orphan Annie nuclei with psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest subacute thyroiditis, a type of thyroiditis characterized by mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. Fibrosis of the stroma is characteristic of Riedel’s thyroiditis, amyloid stroma is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma, and orphan Annie nuclei with psammoma bodies are characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The enlarged and tender thyroid gland along with the decreased TSH level indicate thyroiditis. Mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells is a histopathologic finding commonly seen in thyroiditis. Option A describes Hashimoto's thyroiditis, option B describes medullary thyroid carcinoma, and option D describes papillary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diffuse enlargement and tenderness of the thyroid gland, along with laboratory findings suggest thyroiditis. Mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells is consistent with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis or De Quervain's thyroiditis, which is the most common type of thyroiditis. The other options are not characteristic of thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a diffuse thyroid enlargement, tenderness, and elevated ESR suggests subacute thyroiditis, which is often associated with a mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. None of the other options are characteristic of subacute thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with tenderness to palpation and laboratory findings suggest subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain's thyroiditis. The most likely histopathologic findings would be mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. Extensive fibrosis of the stroma would be seen in Riedel's thyroiditis, sheets of polygonal cells in amyloid stroma in medullary thyroid cancer, and orphan Annie nuclei with psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings point to subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, which is characterized by mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. The other options are not consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain's thyroiditis, which is characterized by mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells, making option (C) the correct answer. Extensive fibrosis of the stroma is characteristic of Riedel’s thyroiditis. Sheets of polygonal cells in amyloid stroma can be seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma. Orphan Annie nuclei with psammoma bodies are seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest subacute thyroiditis, which is most commonly associated with mixed cellular infiltration with multinuclear giant cells. Options A, B, and D are associated with other thyroid disorders.
